docs.title: Welcome to ReadShade
docs.text: ReadShade is a documentation site designed with simplicity and neutrality in mind. We aim to provide a straightforward and accessible platform for everyone to contribute and share knowledge. We've removed unnecessary complexity and barriers, ensuring that anyone can join our community.

docs.title: Striving for Neutrality
docs.text: We strive to remain neutral in our approach, avoiding conflict of interest.

docs.title: Simple to Contribute
docs.text: We want to make it easy for anyone to contribute to ReadShade, regardless of their technical background. We've chosen Python and MkDocs Material as our core technologies. You can start creating and editing documentation quickly with just these two tools. There is no need to worry about complicated setup or configuration - install Python and MkDocs Material, and you're ready to go.

docs.title: Shader Toggler
docs.text:
The Shader Toggler is a powerful tool for disabling or toggling shaders in games. This guide will walk you through the process of using the Shader Toggler add-on with ReShade.

For this guide, we will be using a free game called "Mimic Search," which can be downloaded from Steam.

docs.title: Preface
docs.text: To get started, you will need to download the ReShade add-on version. You can find more information on this here.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text: To use the Shader Toggler, you will need to download the add-on itself from the official GitHub repository. Make sure to download the correct version for your game.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Install the game and ReShade with the ShaderToggler.addon64. Ensure that all other ReShade shaders are turned off to avoid conflicts.

docs.title: 1. Accessing the Add-on
docs.text:
Launch the game and access the ReShade menu. Navigate to the add-on tab:

Minimize other add-ons to make it clearer. Ensure you are in the game and have a problematic effect like Chromatic Aberration visible:

docs.title: 2. Setting Up the Add-on
docs.text: Move the ReShade menu to the right and press "New." The menu will change, and you should click on "Edit":

docs.title: 3. Configuring the Add-on
docs.text: Enter a name for the effect, such as "CA 01," in the "Name Box":

docs.title: 4. Setting Up a Shortcut
docs.text:
Set up a shortcut, such as "Ctrl + 1", for the first group. Click the "Shortcut Box" and press the shortcut keys, then press "OK":

You can choose to activate the add-on at startup or not. Press "OK" again.

docs.title: 5. Hunting for Shaders
docs.text:
Click the "Change shaders" button and let it run for a bit:

The process will look like this:

And then change to this:

docs.title: 6. Navigation and Saving
docs.text:
Use the Num Pad to navigate and save shaders:

  • Keys 1 & 2: Navigation and 3: Save for Pixel Shaders
  • Keys 4 & 5: Navigation and 6: Save for Vertex Shaders
  • Keys 7 & 8: Navigation and 9: Save for Compute Shaders

In this case, we will use keys 1 and 2 to hunt for the shader. Once found, save it by pressing 3:

Click "Done" and press the shortcut to activate the add-on:

The shader should now be disabled. Repeat the process for other shaders in the game.

docs.title: 7. Saving Your Progress
docs.text:
Click the "Save all Toggle Groups" button to save your progress:

The save file will be located where the game exe/add-on is. Here is an example of what the save file might look like:

[General]
AmountGroups=1

[Group0_VertexShaders]
AmountHashes=0

[Group0_PixelShaders]
ShaderHash0=3090188387
AmountHashes=1

[Group0_ComputeShaders]
AmountHashes=0

[Group0]
Name=CA 01
ToggleKey=822083840
IsActiveAtStartup=False

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
With the Shader Toggler, you can now disable or toggle shaders in games. Remember to save your progress and repeat the process for other shaders. Good luck and happy shader hunting!

Here is an image from in-game with the effect disabled:

Chromatic Aberration - Off

docs.title: Introduction to Generic Depth
docs.text: The Generic Depth add-on is a powerful tool for enhancing the depth effects in your games. To get started, you will need to have the add-on version of ReShade installed. You can learn more about the different versions of ReShade here.

docs.title: Downloading the Generic Depth Add-on
docs.text:
To use the Generic Depth add-on, you will need to download it from the official Discord channel. Make sure to select the correct version of the add-on for your game to ensure compatibility.

Please note that using the correct version of the add-on is crucial for optimal performance and to avoid any potential issues.

You can proceed with installing the add-on once you have downloaded the correct version.

docs.title: Reshade Effect Shader Toggler (R.E.S.T)
docs.text: The Reshade Effect Shader Toggler (R.E.S.T) is a powerful tool used to separate effects from the game and layer ReShade shaders under the isolated element.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: To get started with R.E.S.T, you will need to download the add-on from the official GitHub repository.

docs.title: Downloading and Installing the Add-on
docs.text: The release folder contains several files, including shaders, FX files, a license, and a README file. You can ignore the license and README files for now. You will need to use one of the .addon# files, but you can drag both into the same area where the ReShade.dll is located. For this guide, we will focus on the 64-bit add-on.

docs.title: Installing the Add-on
docs.text: Place the ReshadeEffectShaderToggler.addon64 file in the same location where you installed ReShade. This is usually in the game folder, near the dxgi.dll file.

docs.title: Choosing a Game
docs.text: For this guide, we will use the game Wiz⊙rdum. However, you can use R.E.S.T with other games as well.

docs.title: Setting Up the Add-on
docs.text:
Your game folder should look like this:

Make sure you have ReShade installed and the add-on file in the correct location.

docs.title: Launching the Game and Add-on
docs.text:
Start the game, and ReShade should load with the add-on enabled. You can find the add-on in the Add-on Tab:

Click the arrow to open the add-on, and close other add-ons to make it cleaner.

docs.title: Configuring the Add-on
docs.text:
The add-on should look like this:

Close the ReShade menu and go in-game to use the add-on.

docs.title: Setting Up the Add-on in-game
docs.text:
Open ReShade, move it to the right, and click New:

A new window will open:

Follow these steps:

  1. Click Activate [x]
  2. Click Edit
  3. Type a name in the Name field
  4. Create a Shortcut
  5. Click OK

docs.title: Enabling 3D Shader
docs.text: If you want to use SuperDepth3D with R.E.S.T, you need to enable the 3D shader. Open the main menu, enable the 3D shader, and scroll down to the bottom of the shader. Enable REST_UI_MODE by setting it to 1:

docs.title: Configuring the Add-on Settings
docs.text:
Go back to the Add-on Tab and click Settings:

A new window will open:

Follow these steps:

  1. Click off Apply all enabled techniques [ ]
  2. Mark the 3D shader [x]

docs.title: Isolating the UI
docs.text:
Focus on the list of active buffers:

Find the buffer that isolates the UI. Double-click the hex value to select it:

The selected buffer should turn yellow.

docs.title: Saving Your Progress
docs.text: Close the window and click Save all Toggle Groups:

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
You may notice issues with the center crosshair. There are three ways to deal with this:

  1. Check if the game allows you to remove it
  2. Use the ShaderToggler
  3. Mod the game to remove the texture

docs.title: Cursor Adjustments
docs.text:
If you experience issues with the cursor in Side by Side and Top n Bottom formats, go to the Shader Settings and look for Cursor Adjustments:

Set the cursor type to the one you prefer:

You can use Mouse 5 to switch layers.

docs.title: Sharing Your Configuration
docs.text: When you click Save all Toggle Groups, a file called ReshadeEffectShaderToggler.ini is generated in the same folder as the add-on. You can share this file with others by posting it on the ReShade forum.

docs.title: Simulated Reality Displays
docs.text:
Simulated Reality (SR) Displays, formerly known as Dimenco, are now backed by Leia Inc. This guide will help you get SuperDepth3D working on hardware with SR technology.

Main Website: https://www.leiainc.com/

Hardware Developers Links:

  • Acer Spatiallabs
  • ASUS Spatial Vision
  • Sony Spatial Reality

Please note that this guide is intended for hardware with the SR badge:

docs.title: Getting Started with SuperDepth3D
docs.text: To use SuperDepth3D with SR Displays, you can follow either the easy text guide or the manual guide.

docs.title: Video Guide
docs.text:
For a video tutorial, please refer to this video guide.

SuperDepth3D for Simulated Reality Displays.

docs.title: Easy Text Guide
docs.text:
To install ReShade and SuperDepth3D, follow these steps:

  1. Download ReShade: Download the add-on version of ReShade.

  2. Install ReShade: Install ReShade by running the ReShade.exe.

  3. Select Game Executable: Select or browse for the game's executable. In this example, we will install it in Forza Horizon 4.

  4. Click Open.

  5. Select API: Select the API and click next.

  6. Select SuperDepth3D: Select the Depth3D Repo and check SuperDepth3D.fx.

  7. Click Next.

  8. Select 3DGameBridgeProjects Add-on: Make sure to select the 3DGameBridgeProjects add-on.

Click Next and then Finish.

docs.title: Manual Guide
docs.text:
If you prefer a more manual approach, follow these steps:

  1. Install ReShade: Install ReShade or inject it into your game, ensuring you use the add-on version of ReShade.

    If ReShade is already installed, you can skip this step.

  2. Download 3DGameBridge: Download the latest version of 3DGameBridge.

  3. Copy Add-ons: Copy both add-ons or just the one you need, based on the game's architecture.

  4. Paste Add-ons: Paste the add-ons where the game's executable is located or where the ReShade .dll is installed.

    Please start the game to see if it works.

docs.title: Important Notes
docs.text:
When starting the game, you may need to set your primary monitor to the Simulated Reality Display. If not, the game may not select the correct screen, resulting in a black screen.

Additionally, ensure the game is running at its native resolution for the 3D display. If the resolution is too small, the image may appear distorted.

docs.title: VITURE
docs.text:
VITURE is a leading brand in the AR glasses market, offering a unique gaming experience. This guide is designed to help you set up your VITURE Gen 1 Glasses with SuperDepth3D, depending on your GPU.

VITURE is one of the key players in the AR glasses industry.

docs.title: Setting Up VITURE with Intel GPU
docs.text: To use your VITURE AR Glasses with an Intel GPU, follow these steps:

docs.title: Initial Steps
docs.text:
1. Update your Arc Drivers: Ensure you have the latest Arc Drivers installed.

  2. Download Intel Graphics Command Center: Install the Intel Graphics Command Center beta application.

docs.title: Configuring VITURE with Intel GPU
docs.text:
1. Switch to 3D Mode: Plug in your VITURE AR Glasses and switch them to 3D Mode by holding down the first button for a few seconds.

    Under Windows, it should be recognized as a 3840 x 1080p screen:

    If you see this, it's a good sign.

  2. Launch Intel Graphics Command Center: Start the Intel Graphics Command Center (BETA).

  3. Select Display Settings: Click on Display.

  4. Select VITURE Screen: Click on the VITURE screen.

  5. Change Resolution: Go to settings and change the resolution from 3840 x 1080 to 1920 x 1080.

  6. Set Scale Size: Change the scale size to Stretched.

  7. Verify Settings: Your settings should now look like this:

Now you can start your game with SuperDepth3D and enjoy it in stereo 3D.

docs.title: Setting Up VITURE with NVIDIA GPU
docs.text:
To use your VITURE AR Glasses with an NVIDIA GPU, follow these steps:

  1. Update your NVIDIA Drivers: Ensure you have the latest NVIDIA Drivers installed.

  2. Switch to 3D Mode: Plug in your VITURE AR Glasses and switch them to 3D Mode by holding down the first button for a few seconds.

    Under Windows, it should be recognized as a 3840 x 1080p screen:

    If you see this, it's a good sign.

  3. Launch NVIDIA Control Panel: Start the NVIDIA Control Panel.

  4. Change Resolution: Click on Change Resolution and set it to 1920 x 1080.

  5. Adjust Desktop Size and Position: Go to Adjust Desktop size and Position, set it to Fullscreen, and the rest should default to the correct values.

Now you can start your game with SuperDepth3D and enjoy it in stereo 3D.

docs.title: PCSX2
docs.text: This guide provides basic adjustments for ReShade and its use in PCSX2: Emulator.

docs.title: Introduction to PCSX2 Settings
docs.text: We will be using the DX11 API for this guide due to its compatibility with other add-ons.

docs.title: Display Settings
docs.text:
To access the display settings, navigate to the menu shown below.

  1. Fullscreen Mode & Aspect Ratio: Set the aspect ratio to "Fit to Window" as shown below.

    This is necessary because the depth buffer is set to this internally.

  2. Anti-Blur: Enable this option to minimize distortions.

docs.title: Rendering
docs.text: We will be using the DX11 API for rendering. You can try different APIs as long as you can get a depth buffer output.

docs.title: Rendering Options
docs.text:
To access the rendering settings, navigate to the menu shown below.

  1. Rendering: Set the rendering to "Direct3D 11" as shown below.

    This ensures compatibility with most of ReShade's add-ons.

  2. Internal Resolution: Set the internal resolution to "Native" for most cases.

    This also helps with ReShade's generic depth add-on.

docs.title: Installing and Configuring ReShade
docs.text:
To use ReShade with PCSX2, follow these steps:

  1. Install ReShade under your current API setting. You can find the installation guide here.
  2. Turn off the emulator and install ReShade.
  3. Start your game and go into the ReShade menu.

  4. Check the depth buffer in the add-ons tab.

docs.title: Additional Information
docs.text: Make sure to complete any additional setup, such as configuring games and BIOS, on your end.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: This guide provides a good starting point for using ReShade with PCSX2. However, note that the optimal settings may vary depending on the game.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This guide provides two methods for disabling DLSS Frame Generation, a feature that can cause crashes when starting or playing games. The first method will disable it globally for all games on Windows, while the second method will demonstrate how to disable it for a specific game.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: You do not need this method on Intel and AMD setups.

docs.title: Method 1: Global Disable
docs.text: To disable DLSS Frame Generation globally, follow these steps:

docs.title: Step-by-Step Instructions
docs.text:
1. Access Display Settings: Go to Display Settings on your Windows system.

  2. Navigate to Graphics Settings: Next, go to System > Display > Graphics and click on Change default graphics settings.

  3. Locate Hardware Accelerated GPU Scheduling: After clicking on the above option, look for Hardware Accelerated GPU Scheduling.

  4. Disable Hardware Accelerated GPU Scheduling: Turn off Hardware Accelerated GPU Scheduling.

  5. Restart Your PC: Reset your PC to apply the changes, which should globally disable Frame Generation.

docs.title: Method 2: Game-Specific Disable
docs.text:
For this demonstration, we will use Ghost Runner 2 as an example. Most games will have a similar process.

To disable DLSS Frame Generation for a specific game, follow these steps:

docs.title: Step-by-Step Instructions
docs.text:
1. Locate the nvngx_dlssg.dll File: You will be looking for a file called nvngx_dlssg.dll. In this case, it's located in the Streamline folder:

2. Rename the nvngx_dlssg.dll File: Rename nvngx_dlssg.dll to nvngx_dlssg.back.

docs.title: Example Screenshot
docs.text: Here's an example screenshot of the game with DLSS Frame Generation disabled:

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: That's it for now. We will post more examples for other games later. Good luck with disabling DLSS Frame Generation, and we hope this guide has been helpful in resolving any issues you may have encountered.

docs.title: Deleting Post Effects on Unreal Engine
Introduction
docs.text: This guide provides instructions on how to delete or disable post effects on Unreal Engine 4 and Unreal Engine 5 games. The steps outlined in this guide can help improve performance and reduce visual issues.

docs.title: Unreal Engine 4
docs.text:
The following post effects can be disabled in Unreal Engine 4 games:

  • Motion Blur
  • Depth of Field
  • Chromatic Aberration

docs.title: Phase 1: Editing the Engine.ini File
docs.text:
To disable these effects, follow these steps:

  1. Locate the Engine.ini File: Head over to %APPDATA% or %LOCALAPPDATA% and navigate to the game's configuration directory:

    • Steam: "GAME"\Saved\Config\WindowsNoEditor
    • Windows Game Store: "GAME"\Saved\Config\WinGDK

  2. Edit the Engine.ini File: Open the Engine.ini file and add the following lines at the bottom:

[SystemSettings]
r.DepthOfFieldQuality=0
r.MotionBlur.Max=0
r.MotionBlurQuality=0
r.DefaultFeature.MotionBlur=0
r.SceneColorFringe.Max=0
r.SceneColorFringeQuality=0
  1. Save and Set to Read-Only: Save the file and set it to Read Only to prevent accidental changes.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Keep in mind that changing settings in-game may require a restart to apply the changes made to the Engine.ini file.
  • This method may not work in every instance, and results may vary.
  • For more information on modding the Engine.ini file, visit the PC Gaming Wiki.

docs.title: Unreal Engine 5
docs.text:
Note: Unreal 5 games will be a case-by-case basis until we release an addon to disable specific effects.

Unreal Engine 5 games require different settings to disable post effects. The following example is for HellBlade 2:

[SystemSettings]
r.SceneColorFringeQuality=0
r.Tonemapper.GrainQuantization=0
r.Tonemapper.Quality=0
r.NT.Lens.Distortion.Intensity=0
r.NT.Lens.Distortion.Stretch=0
r.NT.Lens.ChromaticAberration.Intensity=0
r.NT.DOF.RotationalBokeh=0
r.NT.DOF.NTBokehTransform=0
r.FilmGrain=0

To remove letterboxing, add the following lines:

r.NT.AllowAspectRatioHorizontalExtension=0
r.NT.EnableConstrainAspectRatio=0

docs.text: The Shader Toggler is a free ReShade add-on that can disable certain effects that may cause issues with Depth3D. You can learn more about it in our ReShade guide.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Choosing the right version of ReShade can be confusing, but don't worry, we're here to help. In this guide, we'll walk you through the process of selecting the best ReShade version for your needs.

docs.title: Am I going to play online or offline?
docs.text: This is an important question because it determines which version of ReShade you should use. If you're playing an online game, you'll want to use the add-on version, which has Network Detection disabled. You can download it from the official ReShade website. Just scroll to the bottom of the page and click on the second button.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: Keep in mind that you may not always want to use the add-on version. If you're playing a single-player game, the normal version of ReShade is sufficient. You can also download it from the same website, but this time, click on the first button.

docs.title: Do I need a special version of ReShade for the game?
docs.text: In some cases, you may need to download a special version of ReShade for a particular game. For example, this version of ReShade is made to work with Dragon's Dogma 2 alongside the REFramework.

docs.title: Important
docs.text: If you're playing a single-player game but need to use an add-on, you can download the ReShade version with add-on support from the official website. This version supports almost all add-ons, including those found here.

docs.title: Where can I get an older version of ReShade?
docs.text:
If you need an older version of ReShade, there are several ways to get it. For versions 3.0.0 and earlier:

  1. You can download it directly from the ReShade website: https://reshade.me/downloads/ReShade_Setup_x.x.x.exe.
  2. For versions 5.0.0 and later, use this link.

docs.title: Alternative Method
docs.text: If the version you need is no longer available on the website, you can try using the ReShade Repository or this Mega.nz link.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: You may need to download an older version of ReShade for certain games, such as Fallout, NV Fallout 3, or The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion.

docs.title: I want to play Elden Ring. It's an online game with EAC. Can I do this?
docs.text: Yes, you can play Elden Ring with ReShade. The game's developers allow the use of ReShade, so you can use the add-on version. However, not all games with EAC will work with ReShade. For example, Lords of the Fallen will not launch with any version of ReShade, and you'll need to disable EAC to use it. If you do disable EAC, use the add-on version of ReShade.

docs.title: Introduction to DPI Scaling Issues
docs.text: Have you ever experienced blurry text, images, videos, websites, or games on your Windows system? This issue can also affect the performance and clarity of ReShade and Depth3D. The culprit behind this problem is often related to the Windows DPI (Dots Per Inch) settings. In this guide, we will walk you through a step-by-step process to resolve this issue and improve the overall visual quality of your games and applications.

docs.title: Identifying the Problem
docs.text:
The symptoms of DPI scaling issues can manifest in various ways, including:

  • Blurry or pixelated text and images
  • Distorted or stretched videos and websites
  • Poor game performance and graphics quality
  • ReShade and Depth3D not functioning as expected

docs.title: Resolving DPI Scaling Issues
docs.text: To fix the DPI scaling issue, follow these simple steps:

docs.title: Step 1: Accessing the Game's Properties
docs.text:
1. Locate the game's executable file: Find the .exe file associated with the game you want to fix.
  2. Right-click on the executable file: Click on the game's executable file with your right mouse button.
  3. Select Properties: From the context menu, select the Properties option.

docs.title: Step 2: Adjusting the Compatibility Settings
docs.text:
1. Select the Compatibility tab: In the Properties window, click on the Compatibility tab.
  2. Click on Change High DPI Settings: In the Compatibility tab, click on the Change High DPI Settings button.
  3. Override high DPI scaling behavior: At the bottom of the window, check the box next to Override high DPI scaling behavior.
  4. Select the scaling mode: Open the pull-down menu and select Application.

docs.title: Example Screenshot
docs.text: For reference, here is an example screenshot of the Windows DPI settings window:

docs.title: Global DPI Scaling Solution
docs.text:
While the above steps provide a solution for individual games, there may be a global way to adjust the DPI settings for all applications. However, the effectiveness of this approach may vary across different versions of the Windows operating system. If you're interested in exploring a global solution, you can search for additional resources and tutorials online.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the DPI scaling issue and enjoy clearer text, images, and videos in your games and applications.
